title: Survival Analysis: Theory and Applications
text:
Survival analysis is a branch of statistics that deals with the analysis of time-to-event data. In clinical trials, the event usually refers to a specific outcome such as death, disease recurrence, recovery, or relapse. The goal is to analyze the time it takes for the event to occur, while accounting for the fact that not all participants may experience the event during the study period (censoring).
‚Ä¶
üß¨ Survival analysis is a fundamental tool to understand and compare the prognosis of patients under different treatments, essential for evidence-based medicine.

title: Survival Analysis in R
text:
This project demonstrates Kaplan-Meier estimation using survival and ggplot2 in R.


library(survival)
library(ggplot2)

km_fit <- survfit(Surv(AVAL, CNSR) ~ TRTP, data = adtte)
ggsurvplot(km_fit)



Survival analysis is a key analysis in oncology trials, especially for endpoint analysis like Progression-Free Survival (PFS) and Overall Survival (OS).

title: Bioinformatics Analysis Flow (Gene Expression & Survival)
text:
This section documents a full bioinformatics analysis pipeline combining gene expression data and clinical survival data.


This includes: - Gene expression data (GSE7390_expression.csv) - Clinical metadata (GSE7390_metadata.csv)




Quality Control (removal of low-expression genes)
Normalization (log2 transformation or z-score)





Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
Clustering (heatmap or unsupervised clustering)





Compare gene expression between survivors and non-survivors
Identify significantly differentially expressed genes (DEGs)





Multivariate Cox model incorporating both clinical covariates and DEGs




TFLs produced: - Table: Top 10 survival-associated genes - Listing: Patient list with molecular and clinical features - Figure: Heatmap of expression by clinical group



All the above will be combined into this page and made available in the portfolio.



Bioinformatics Flowchart

title: Agile Methodologies
text:
Agile in Clinical Programming
As the clinical programming industry evolves, the need for agility grows stronger. Traditional waterfall models are being replaced with Scrum-inspired approaches, where cross-functional teams collaborate continuously.

Sprint-based programming (TFL production in cycles).
Early validation and continuous feedback.
Collaboration between data management, programming, and biostatistics.

This section will grow as I continue exploring and applying Agile methodologies in clinical programming.

title: About Me
text:
About Me
My journey started in Electronic Engineering, but I soon realized I wanted to work closer to the healthcare field. That‚Äôs how I transitioned into Biomedical Engineering, combining technology with a passion for health.
From the beginning, my work always revolved around data analysis ‚Äî first in hardware (processor data), then in business intelligence, and finally in clinical trials. This constant evolution helped me develop both technical programming skills and a strong sense of how data can tell the story of a product‚Äôs development.
What truly inspires me is seeing how clinical trial data reflects the real-world impact a treatment can have ‚Äî from initial data cleaning and reporting, to seeing that product eventually reach the market and help thousands of people.

Every dataset is a story of lives transformed ‚Äî and I‚Äôm proud to help write those stories.

title: Clinical Trial Analysis Flow (CDISC)
text:
This section documents the full process of a regulatory-compliant clinical trial analysis, following CDISC standards.


This includes: - Demographics (age, sex, treatment group) - Clinical Events (relapse, recurrence, etc.) - Disposition (dropout, completion) - Time-to-event (TTE) data



SDTM datasets produced: - DM - Demographics - CE - Clinical Events - DS - Disposition



ADaM datasets produced: - ADTTE - Time to Event dataset (ready for survival analysis)



TFLs produced: - Table: Population summary table (age, sex, etc.) - Listing: List of key events per patient - Figure: Kaplan-Meier survival plot



All the above will be combined into this page and made available in the portfolio.



Clinical Flowchart

title: Survival Analysis - SAS vs R
text:
This section demonstrates a parallel analysis comparing the creation of a Kaplan-Meier survival curve using both SAS and R. We are using the dataset derived from GSE7390, simulating an ADTTE structure (Time to Event Analysis dataset).



The dataset used for this analysis is: - GSE7390_metadata.csv (with columns: SampleID, Treatment, Age, TimeToEvent, Event)






* Import the CSV into a SAS dataset;
proc import datafile="GSE7390_metadata.csv"
    out=work.adtte
    dbms=csv
    replace;
    getnames=yes;
run;



# Load data into R
adtte <- read.csv("GSE7390_metadata.csv")







proc lifetest data=adtte plots=survival;
    time TimeToEvent*Event(0);
    strata Treatment;
run;



library(survival)
library(survminer)

fit <- survfit(Surv(TimeToEvent, Event) ~ Treatment, data = adtte)

ggsurvplot(fit, data = adtte, pval = TRUE, risk.table = TRUE, ggtheme = theme_minimal())
ggsave("survival_analysis_output_R.png", dpi = 300)







(This image should be manually generated in SAS and saved to the projects/survival_analysis/ folder as survival_analysis_output_SAS.png)













Treatment
n
Events
Median Survival




Chemo
XX
XX
XX months


Placebo
XX
XX
XX months







This example highlights how to perform the same analysis in both environments, providing flexibility to transition from SAS to R while ensuring traceability.

title: üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
text:
Run this command to regenerate all site files (HTML):
quarto render

title: üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
text:
Add the modified CSS file (and any other changes):
git add styles.css
If you made changes to other files (like .qmd), you can add them too:
git add .

title: üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
text:
Write a meaningful commit message:
git commit -m "Fix dropdown menu colors and update styles"

title: üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
text:
Send your updates to the GitHub repository:
git push origin main

title: üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
text:
Visit your website at:
https://YOUR_USERNAME.github.io/YOUR_REPO/
Note: Sometimes GitHub Pages may take 1-2 minutes to refresh the new changes.

title: üì¶ How to Update CSS and Push to GitHub Pages
text:
Remember to adjust quarto.yml if you add new sections or projects.
You can repeat this workflow for any update in content (QMD), style (CSS), or structure (YML).


üß¨ ‚ÄúEmpowering clinical data science with style and clarity.‚Äù
